div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: BRITISH FLOUR FOR EGYPT.
div.p: In an article on Egypt's increasing importations of flour the "Miller" says : A short time ago we briefly commented upon the fact that although Egypt was importing larger quantities of wheat flour every year the British miller was not increasing his share of the trade in a corresponding ratio, Roughly speaking Egypt now takes over a million .sack- yearly, and there is no apparent reason why the United Kingdom should net have a better showing against other countries, and especially against the French miller, who up to the present has had the lion's share of the trade with 700,000 sacks for last year compare: with 70,000 sacks originating here. This is 10 to one in sporting parlance, and the odd, are too long. It is quite true that our millers have doubled their quantity during last yea: seeing that in 1905 only 34,000 sacks were sent out, and there is nothing, or should be nothing, to prevent a still greater increase. The imports into Egypt of no other article during

the last two years show such a great increase as flour and grain of various sorts. Of course, we remember that opportunity served very well, seeing that these years were of the lean kind in Egypt, both wheat and maize being disappointing in yield ; but the opportunity must, or ought to, be followed up with increased assiduity in order to make the business a permanent one, remembering, also, that the population is constantly increasing and that cereal growing is giving place to cotton, which pays better. Besides that, the standard of living is rapidly being raised and new towns and industries are being established, We may also remember another thing Not long since one of the largest machinery orders ever given anywhere was secured by an English firm of four milling engineers for a plant in South America, and the mill will very soon beat work. Behind that again yet another mill quite as large is to be built upon the most modern lines, to make flour for export to Europe. In the Argentine « powerful syndicate has come to the conclusion that it will be more profitable to export flour than wheat, and before long it will be during it, so that we have one more reason for exhorting the home miller to get farther afield before the crush comes, to get established before the days of greater struggling begin to dawn' It is a comparatively easy task to hold the home fort in the top grades, but the medium and the residue are both likely to get more troublesome every year. 'The British palate is a mighty particular one in these days, and everything in flour below the top grade is unsuited to it, and we single out Egypt and Scandinavia as typical countries where there ought to be a sufficient outlet for that residue, given the grit and push which is supposed to be characteristic of our mental and physical embodiment.

div.head: INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL FOR THE BLIND IN ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Countess of Meath sends us the following communication : On various occasions you have kindly promoted the cause of ® most useful institution "The Industrial School for the Blind" in Alexandria. This establishment was one of those fortunate enough to be allowed to show its wares at the Agricultural Exhibition in Cairo opened this afternoon by H.H. the Khedive, who graciously visited the stall allotted to the Blind School, and thus gave Lord Meath, who was present, an opportunity to tell his Highness that it was this institution which first introduced European wicker work into Egypt This industry is now being taken up in several other establishments, and notably in Egyptian prisons It is much to be hoped that criminal labour - though in itself good for those engaged in it — will not be permitted to under sell that done by honest hands, and thus spoil the market. Five pupils from the Blind School at Alexandria were present, and it is gratifying to find what skillful workmen they have become under the instruction of English teachers. One of the former attracted a good deal of notice by the ease with which he was reading and writing Traille type. This institution, unlike the interesting one established at Zeitoun, has never accepted an Egyptian Government grant, as it is the exclusive property of the Ministering Childrens League, a society started in England for the purpose of training children to lead unselfish lives and to take an active interest in the needs of the poor and suffering. The Association has now the proud record of having initiated the foundation of 17 buildings devoted to charity in different parts of the world, Some of them are even found in distant Australasia, as in all four quarters of the globe this society has its branches. No less than 32 centres of work have been established lately in Russia. The Blind School in Alexandria has during the 8 or 9 years of its existence been fortunate enough to secure many friends bat, it needs still more who will kindly assist the blind in the best way, namely, by helping them to help themselves. A new teacher has lately come out from England, who will keep a good stock of wares in band, and will also gladly take orders for any special articles es to meet the needs of customers.

div.head: A Cinematograph Configuration.
div.p: Last evening at about 8 o'clock while the Cinematograph was being exhibited at Esperanza Hall outside the Railway Terminus, the appearance caught on fire. There was a large audience present, but they dispersed in an orderly manner and there 'was no stampede, The entire cinematograph apparatus and a small portion of the Esperanza Hall were burnt out. The damage to the machinery and films is estimated at from £300 te £900. The Alexandria Fire Brigade, under Yoosbashi Waller, was very prompt in arriving on the scene and within ten minutes of the call the fire was extinguished.

div.head: Post Office Notice.
div.p: A Post Office notice states that in order to avoid the necessary of having to advance the hour for closing the despatch of registered correspondence, especially for abroad, banks and commercial houses, having large quantities of such correspondence, are very earnestly requested to send, as much as possible of it early to the post, only keeping what is necessary to the last moment. This will give sufficient time for the completion of registration formalities and also avoid the delay to messengers now caused by the sudden and late arrival of a very large quantity of articles for registration.

div.head: "Omielet-Hesed."
div.p: A very successful Fancy DrassePall was given by the above Alexandrian Benevolent. Society at the Rooms of the French Artistic Union on Saturday evening. Masqueraders were slow in arriving, but dancing commenced with a fair assembly at 10.15 p.m. By midnight the members had been considerably increased, and there were by this time some three to four hundred people present with occasional parties still arriving. These late comers were in some instance, unfortunate enough to find themselves caught in the severe storm which passed over about 11 o'clock. The costumes were pretty and varied, the music good, a pregramme of 14 dances keeping the happy throng engaged until the morning hours. Altogether a very enjoyable evening was spent and what if the room was rather crowded, the atmosphere a trifle stuffy, and the evening really too warm for dancing, so long as is understood the fonds of the Society will be considerably benefitted!

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: EXTRAORDINARY DEMANDS.
ANIMATED DISCUSSIONS.

Yesterday's meeting of the General Assembly was unprecedented for the animation with which the discussions of the many and various demands brought forward was carried on. The Assembly debated all the morning until midday and resumed its deliberations in the afternoon at: 8 o'clock and did not adjourn until late in the evening. The resolutions proposing the enlargement of Tantah railway station and that the estates of intestate Moslems should be devoted to charitable purposes were passed without opposition. The greatest interest was shown in the proposal that the Arabic language should be the sole vehicle of instruction in all the Government schools, whether primary, secondary, or superior. Siad Pasha Zaghloal strongly opposed this measure is a most eloquent speech. He declared that neither the text books nor the teaching staffs were available for the purpose and he deprecated the resolution as premature and calculated to injore the cause of education in Egypt if it were given effect to. In spite of his speech the resolution was carried with only five dissentients. "The most important resolution next discussed was that that full parliamentary institutions should be given to the Egyptian people, who should have entire control of the financial and other administrations. Pending the development of these institutions it was demanded that the powers of the Legislative Council should be largely increased. 'This resolution was carried by a large majority. A member who advocated the improvement and reform of the Wakfs Administration met with no support. Another member, who proposed that free education should be guaranteed by a rate on land also met with no support.

div.head: K.S.C TENNIS TOURNAMENT
div.p: THE EQYPTIAN COMMAND.

The following is the full text of Mr Haldane's statement on the forthcoming change in the Egyptian command. It is contained in the customary memorandum of the Secretary of State for War, which accompanies the Army estimates of effective and non-effective services, which were published a few days ago : For many years the Commanders-in-Chief at Malta and Gibraltar have also been charged with the responsibilities of the civil government of those Colonies; and it has been necessary to provide a complete staff, general, administrative, and personal, on a liberal scale at each station. At the same time these two commands, as well as the third Mediterranean command of Egypt, have been entirely independent of one another, with out any provision for coordination except through the War Office itself. In view of the progress made with decentralization from the War Office, it has been decided to appoint a purely military Commander-in-Chief, with no civil duties, for the Mediterranean as a whole, to be stationed at Mita. No increase in cost of any kind will result from the new arrangements.

div.head: The Agricultural Show
div.p: ALLEN. ALDERSON'S EXHIBITS.

The first stand on the right, on entering the show ground, is occupied by Messr. Allen, Alderson and Company Limited, of Alexandria and Cairo, who exhibit a considerable number of interesting engines and machines. The pair of 20. H.P. ploughing engines, manufactured by Messrs. John Fowler & Co. (Leide) Ltd. with their implements are conspicuously placed in front of this stand, needless to say they are beautifully finished and in every respect among the leading articles in this line. We understand that Messrs, Allen, Alderson and Company Limited had prepared three sets of tackle for this show, but both the 12 H.P. and 16 H.P. set were sold a few days since and it was impossible to spare them for the time necessary for the show. Alongside these engines is one of Messrs. Ruston, Proctor and Co. Ltd. well known Tibbin-making trashing machines in motion. Here again we understand other machines possessing specially interesting features for Upper Egypt prepared for the show, had to be delivered to buyers and were consequently lost for exhibition purposes. We were informed that last year Messrs. Ruston, Proctor and Co. Limited made and delivered 986 thrashing machines in all, a number which we believe has never been beaten as the production of one firm in this line. The various portable steam and oil engines exhibited on this stand call for no special comment beyond tbe statement that they were all np to the usual standard of the makers. We ware specially interested in the new pattern helical pumps by Messrs. Ruston, Proctor and Co. Limited, of which quite a number were on show. These pumps are evidently great favorites, as we notice many of them on the stands of others makers being driven by various motors, and the "Ecols des Artiet Metiers" have a beautifully finished model of one of them on their stand. Messrs. Alien, Alderson and Company Limited, also show a very interesting deep lift centrifugal pump for wells 50 ft. deep, driven by a 5 H.P. oil engine. This was de designed for Upper Egypt, where there are hundreds of wells on which a sakieh was erected, irrigating about 5 to 6 feddans. The cattle plague stopped many of these and this small pump and engine was prepared to take be place of the sakiehs. It cannot fail to be a boon to the man of small means. The same may be said of the 2. H.P. oil engine and 8 helical pump on the same stand, which is a corresponding plant for Lower Egypt. We cannot conclude this notice without alluding to the 40 g. H.P. as suction plant and engine on this stand, this a beautiful piece of work, made by Ruston, Proctor and Co. Limited, and we bear that Messrs. Allen, Alderson and Co. Limited have sold a considerable number of these, all of which are giving the utmost satisfaction, they are suitable for corn mills, centrifugal pumps, electric lighting and the hundreds of oases where a moderate amount of power is required, combined with the utmost economy. We were informed that the Aboukir Co. Ltd. has lately installed two of these with centrifugal pumps, on their estates near Ramleh, and were much pleased with them. Messrs. Allen, Alderson and Co. Limited have had a special and long experience in this line, as previous to Messrs Ruston, Proctor and Co. Limited taking up the manufacture they erected a number of plants made by other continental firms. We noticed a good show of Messrs F. Reddaway and Co. Ltd's famous "Camel" brand belting. This article has made its way all over the world and we need add little beyond stating that here as elsewhere we were told it was the belt of the future. In conclusion we may say that we were glad to see so good a show from the oldest firm in the machinery line in Egypt, as there is often too much of a disposition to rest on their laurels in long established businesses. Messrs. Alter, Alderson and Co. Limited show however that they mean to move with the ime, and if possible keep a little ahead of it.

div.head: ARTHUR KOPPEL LTD.
div.p: This well known firm of world-wide reputation has exhibited a number of very interesting specimens of railway material of every description. We especially noticed a complete installation of light railway plant, in connection with steel tipping, wagons drawn by a locomotive of 600 m/m gauge, the working of which was much admired. Among other items of interest our attention was called to light and heavy tails and sleepers of various sections points, and crossing, turntables, wheels, and axes, axleboxes and different types of platform and sugarcane wagons used on light railways. All the trucks bearing the mark "Arthur Koppel" combining lightness with strength and durability are of the latest design, fitted with special patent roller bearings" which give a great saving of hauling power. We can therefore highly recommend Messrs. Arthur Koppels' plant to all cultivators, industrials and contractors of this country, which will surely find this material of great value for their respective work.

div.head:
THE "EGYPTIAN STANDARD"
NEW NATIONALIST ORGAN.
THE INAUGURAL TEA
div.p: At 5 o'clock on Saturday afternoon the solemn inaugural ceremony of a five o'clock tea to usher in the "Egyptian Standard" and "L'Etendard Egyptien" took place at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo. All the Egyptian followers of Mustapha Pasha Kamel mastered in force, and the entire "Nationalist Party" were assembled in the Arabic Hall of the hotel, which consequently was almost full of people. The first speech was delivered by the Pasha. We need not deal with the speech of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, for his statements never vary and whether he is writing to 'Le Temps' or the "Figaro" or contributing to his own vernacular organ his speeches contain but a single theme concealed amidst floods of verbosity. It is needless therefore to inform our readers that he again dilated with impassioned eloquence on his great war cry of "Carthago est delenda" and after speaking on this topic for a considerable time sat down amidst the enthusiastic plaudits of his audience.
Next came the French editor of "L'Etenard Egyptien."
M. Saint Ogan's discourse was embellished with some remarkable historical allusions. We extract the following from the exordium:
Gentlemen:

In the eighteenth century and under the ministry of Fleury France remained inactive in presence of the Russian menace against Poland. Fired with indignation, a Frenchman, the Count of Pélo, wished to save his country's honor. He put himself at the head of a body of his compatriots and without instructions of any kind, obeying simply a generous impulse, endeavored to carry assistance to the beleaguered town of Dantzig.
I compare the group of Frenchmen who compose the editorial staff of L'Etenard Egyptian with the above small army.
In his peroration he invokes the Hundred Years' War:—

The cruel and undeserved ordeal of the English Occupation is only a short episode in your long history. Egypt can be patient for she is eternal. Many are the events which have passed before the eyes of the crouching sphinx lost in the meditation of its past.

At the risk of galling a wound that ever bleeds, I will venture to say that when the ordeal to which I have referred is over, it will not have proved injurious to Egypt. For it is from the rude contact with the foreigner that nations rise to self-consciousness. In France the national sentiment dates from the Hundred Years' War. We too have experienced an English Occupation and it is thanks to it that we learnt we were Frenchmen.

In the same way the soul of the Egyptian Fatherland is gathering strength today from its efforts to regenerate the country and prepare the way for the future when its head will be reared to the height of its destiny.

Many among the audience failed to catch the similitude between the Hundred Years' War and the British Occupation, but it is considered that the French Editor meant to darkly allude to the chance of Mme Juliette Adam becoming an Egyptian Joan of Arc. At any rate, M. Sant Ogan's speech was much applauded. The next orator was the English Editor of "The Egyptian Standard" Mr. Charles Rudy, who together with Mr. Moloney, are to guide the fortunes of the new paper under the Pasha's direction.
We need not give Mr. Rudy's speech in full. The following preliminary remarks of that gentleman will suffice:—

Gentlemen.— It will necessary for me to explain to you Mr. Maloney's and my presence among you here today, the reason why we have come to Cairo to work under Moustafa Kamel Pasha's guidance on the editorial staff of "The Egyptian Standard."

Before our arrival we heard and read about the foreign autocratic government which is endeavoring to throttle Egyptian independence. We learnt how it had come to the Nile Valley to advise the Egyptian Government, to restore order before leaving and to teach the people how to govern themselves. We had read about treaties signed in the name of the British nation, and promises made by statesmen in the name of the British nation. These treaties and promises have proved to be empty, however; they were looked upon as worthless sheets of papers and hollow word, involving the honour and dignity of no nation. We were surprised, Mr. Manoley and I, at this disregard for given word. We could not understand it. Surely statesmen and signatories —all of them British— could bear their country no such ill-will as to cause her name to be looked at askance abroad. For was not England one of the bulwarks of progress and civilization? Was she not a free nation? How could she then tyrannize over a foreign people, a country which was neither a colony nor a protectorate, but a friend? I repeat it, gentlemen, we could not understand it! We were surprised to learn the ins and outs of certain happenings: in the Nile Valley; some even disgusted us when the gold palm with which they had been disguised wore off etc., etc.
After Mr. Rudy had finished the Pacha made another long speech and then a tea,"à l'anglaise" be it noted, was served and success to the new papers was drunk in tea.

The "Egyptian Standard" made its first appearance yesterday morning. It contains a number of articles all written in the style, which the anglophobe vernacular Press has made us acquainted with for years past with the sole difference that English and not Arabic is the medium.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL"
div.p: Bishop Blyth, the Bishop in Jerusalem and the East, is leaving Alexandria to-morrow for Port Said, where he will hold s confirmation.

The latest arrivals at Shepheard's Hotel include Sir Holled and Lady Smith, Lord Norrys, Sir Richard Tempe, Mr. and Mme Chartran; Comte Werkheim, Comtesse Pallavicini, Baron and Baronne de Trutenberg, Senator Verbecke and family, Baronne de Leonardi, Comte Imaberg, Marquís de Polignac, Mr. and Mrs. Blair Painter and party, Prof. Osborne and family. Mr. F. C. Allan and party, Mr. and Mrs. Gidfroy Morse, Messrs. Pierce and party, Mr. W. H. Osborn and family, etc.
Sir Charles Wyndham and Miss Mary Moore, who have been spending a few weeks in Assouan. left Cairo on Saturday on their way back to London.

Among the visitors at the Ghezireh Palace are Sir James Blyth Bart., and family, Sir Charles and Lady Dadgeen, Major Pirie, the Hon. Alexander Yorke, Mr. and Mrs, F. Rom, Hon. and Mrs, Hay, Mrs. Hunting-Howell and Miss Makellar, Mrs. and Miss Brocklebank, Lord and Lady Vivian, Mr. Ogilby, Lady Barrows, Baron and Baronness Apfaltern, Sir Spencer Maryon-Wilson Bart. and family, Mr. and Mrs. C. Ritz. Mr. and Mrs. Furness, Mrs, Hodges, Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Cook, Mrs and Miss Borchgrevink, Mrs. Leigh Hunt and family.
Mrs. Iddings will not receive on Wednesdays, for the present, owing to the. death of a near relative.

Miss Carow who has been spending some weeks at the American Agency with Mrs. Iddings will remain a few days in Alexandria as the goest of Judge and Miss Batcheller who are giving a reception in her honor on Tuesday afternoon. Miss Carow is sailing on the 'Hoh nzollern" on Wednesday to join her sister, Mrs. Roosevelt, in Washington.

Among the visitors at the Savoy Hotel, Assonan, are Sir Barrington and Lady Simeon, Lady Baring, Lady A. Baring, Sir Stephen Mackenzi, Sir Thomas Dewar, Lady Norah Hodgson, Count Diepholz, Count Kielmansegg, Baron Wercebe, Count sand Countess Candenhove, Niercziwske, Baron Vreltinghoff, Count and Countess Lehodorff Preye, Baron ani Baroness de Crambrogghe, Count de Rneren, Baroness de Goethals, Colonel and Mrs. Willan, Count von Hagen, Countess Dohna, Major von der Graben, etc.

The Earl and Countess of Lanesborough, Baroness von Butlar, Lady Camoys, Baron de Langsdorff, Colonel Maberly, Count and Countess von Hollnstein, the Hon. Henry Marsham, Lady Winfred Carry, Baron and Baroness de Boulemont, and Lady Louiesa Magennis are staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo.

Other visitors include Sir Leslie and Lady Huntington, Baron de Reutes, Colonel Mitchell, Baron and Baroness Honwald, Major General von Below, Count de la Chesnais, Lady Caroline and Lady Helen Gordon Lennox, Canon and Mrs. Kuox Little, Mr. and Lady Mariel Beckwith, Count and Countess Charles de Zogheb, Lady Newborough, Lady David Tennant, Marquis de Fioravanti.

As a mark of respect for the memory of the late Mrs. Haselden, who was for many years a member of the congregation of St. Mark's Church at Alexandria, and a keen supporter of the Choir, at the close of the Service yesterday morning the "Dead March" was played.

Staff Nurses H.M.E. Macantney and K. Roscoe, of Queen Alexandra's Imperial Military Nursing Service, arrived from England by the transport Sicilia and have been taken on the strength of the Cairo garrison.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY K.S.C FOOTBALL"
div.p: The final of the Big Unit Shield was played at Ghezireh on the 2nd inst., amidst great enthusiasm on the part of a very considerable crowd of spectators. The teams left in being were the Coldstream Guards and the Dublin Fusiliers. The latter team were the favourites, and by superior all round play and better combination gained a well deserved victory by 8 goals to 1. The game throughout was keen, and the football of a high standard, the Dublins were quicker on the ball, their left forward being especially conspicuous for pace and brilliant play. Lieut. Crozier also, outside left, was very sound and safe. The first goal to the Dublins the Guard's goal keeper was caught napping, and the same may be said for the Dublins, when the Guard, scored their one and only goal. The judgment displayed by the Rev. Anderson as referee was highly commendable.

div.head: KHARTOUM AGRICULTURAL SHOW."
div.p: The fifth Annual Agricultural and Industrial show of Khartoum Province was held in the Public Gardens last week, under the patronage of His Excellency, the Governor General. A large number of exhibits were displayed in the usual manner.

In the morning, the exhibits were examined by the committee of judges, and prizes were awarded. In the afternoon the gardens were opened to the public, who came in large numbers. The weather was fine, and the music furnished by the band of the King's Rifles: added considerably to the enjoyment of all present. The Governor General and Lady Wingate visited the exhibition at 4.20 p.m. They were received at the entrance by Miralai Stanton Bey and the Mamur of Khartoum. ' His Excellency was much pleased with the exhibition and expressed his satisfaction to the Governor.

At 5 o'clock refreshments were served at the refreshment pavilion. The Governor entertained those that contributed to the prize fund, to tea and refreshments. His Excellency left the gardens at 6 p.m. after which prizes in cash and in the shape of fancy silver articles, were distributed among the successful exhibitors.

The success of the exhibition is in large measure due to the energy and interest of Miralai Stanton Bey, the Governor of the Province, who was aided by his able staff of officers and officials. On the whole, the exhibition was decidedly in advance of that of last year. With the exception of the silverware department, the industrial section did not make much advance. No carpentry work was exhibited except a number of articles made at the Prison, and, as we are told, not especially designed for the exhibition. The Gordon College Workshops could certainly have sent a creditable exhibit of carpentry work done by their pupils. The first prize for Angarebs was awarded for an angareb of Zin wood, made in the shape of a European bedstead, and carved in a rather bizarre fashion. Mesers. Dilavari exhibited a fine collection of cement pavement. The agricultural section was certainly in advance of former exhibitions. The cotton samples were of very fine quality, much superior to anything hitherto seen. The vegetable collections attracted much attention. There is no doubt but that market gardening would be quite profitable in this country, if well taken in hand, and would supply an important need. Very fine collection of grain of last year's crop were exhibited. On the whole, says the "Sudan Times" the improvement is quite marked though the agricultural section indicates more of it than the industrial. The evidence is clear that the Government is putting forth every reasonable effort to develop the resources, of the country, and by such exhibitions is encouraging Agriculture and Industry, and leading the country forward to a grand destiny.

For particulars apply: A. TASCO, Proprietor, also proprietor of Grand Hotel Karoun, Fayoum.

The progressives claim support in to-day's election on the ground of past services, also on the unique chance of effecting reforms offered by the combination of the Liberal Government with the Progressive Council. Mr. John Burns, who is not a candidate, in a manifesto describes the reformers campaign as the most vulgar and disgraceful which ever discredited British public life. He urges the electors to defeat the monopolists who are endeavoring to make London their prey. The reformers claim that the defeat of the progressives would be a serious blow to the Government. (Reuter)

The County Council elections have resulted in a sweeping defeat for the progressives, 79 moderates, or self-styled municipal reformers, and 89 progressives have been elected, aa compared with 85 moderates and 83 progressives in 1904. The progressives blame the socialists, for the loge of the seats. A reformer won Mr. John Burns' former seat at Baitersea. (Reuter)
The "Jean Bart" is regarded as a total loss : only the armament can be saved : the crew will be distributed over other vessels (Reuter)

Baron Budberg, a member of the Council of the Empire, whilist driving at Reval was attacked by six men. The Baron and his servant were killed and the coachman wounded. The geudarmerie chief of the Transcausian railway was shot dead in the street at Tifle. (Reuter)
493 members of the Duma have been elected, of whom 311 are oppositionists. (Reuter)

Signor Tittoni in the Chamber of the Deputies referring to the recent revolt of the Benadir said that the Government intended to carefully re-organise this region, to engage more native troops, and to establish a wireless telegraph station. (Reuter)

Mr, Winston Churchill, speaking at Oxford, said that the Government could not abolish Chinese labour in South Africa without the consent of the South Africans, he therefore welcomed the new Assembly which would authoritatively pronounce their opinion, but whatever the decision would be the Government would keep its pledges though it required time to carry them out. (Reuter)
Sir August Manns is dead. (Reuter)
The Lower House of California has passed a bill precluding aliens from holding land in California for upwards of 5 years.

Mr. Chamberlain has started for the Riviera. (Reuter)

The "Nene Freie Presse" has interviewed M. De Martens on the second Hague Conference. He said that the main object of the conference would be the formation of a commission to hold an international enquiry. He did not believe that the discussion on disarmament would lead to practical results. (Havas)

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, in an article to the new Liberal weekly paper "The Nation," says that he considers the objections to discussing the limitation of armaments at the Hague conference baseless, and points out that the original conference was convened for that object Great Britain has already shown her sincerity by the reduction in the army and navy. He is convinced that the world recognises that the British naval preponderance is non-aggressive. (Reuter)

div.head: KHARTOUM RIFLE CLUB.
div.p: The third annual meeting of the Khartoum Rifle Club was held on the 20th and 21st inst.

Lady Wingate, who was accompanied by the Governor General, gave away the prizes on the afternoon of the 21st February, in the presence of a large and interested gathering of residents and visitors. The meeting proved a great success and was well attended, there being about 60 competitors.

div.head: OPERA AT CAIRO.
div.p: ABBAS THEATRE

Leoncavallo's Bohème was given to a full house for the first time in Egypt, on Thursday night. It is rather a puzzle at the first hearing. The arrangement of the |book and moso is different, essentially, to that of Puccini ; and yet one has an impression of an unsatisfactory resemblance. For the play we have (1) the scene at the Café Momus, (2) the courtyard of Musette's house, (3) Maice's room—Leon- cavalo makes him a tenor and Rodolphe a baritone and (4) Rodolphe's room where Mimi's death takes place. We have no fair and no Buttes de Mountmartre. Perhaps the chief feature is that sense of humour seems even more absent in Leocavallo than in Puccioi : where Leocavallo wishes to be light he becomes absurd and vulgar. Musette's romance savours of the Café Chantant, his fan becomes roystering and pugnacious, his sentiment thunderous and discursive. The orchestration is one long sequence of eloquent violins wherein other instrumental motives wind in and out. But good as it often is, it does not convince. He has suggestions of "Tosca' in the 3rd act, and of his own work all through. Puccini, is of course, far more obvious, even appropriate : and yet again these Bohèneairs do not seem to find their 'own,' until one hears them retouched and reframed in 'Tosca.' Still, this is only a first impression, and again it is hardly fair to think of modern Italian musician relation to anything but other modern Italian music. One must after all establish a real and not an ideal standard for comparison. Parts of the performance ware excellent. Signor Pomps had more to do than any one as Schannard, and very well he did it : his conducting of the Bohemian 'hymn' in the 2nd act revealed depths of Richter Mottl-Coloune ; he showed what idealism of tremolo can be attained with a feather duster. Ha really sung| well throughout. Signor Isshierdo was good in the third act. His high note of course brought the house down : nothing like a high note in Cairo. It was hard that M. Leoncavallo should in that act make his Soprano| combine pathos and packing, and than force his tenor to roll on a bed and how! Can vulgarity go further. Still Sigs. Ischierdo should not wear such a ghostly concretion of red and black Tartan. Signora Issia was good enough as Musette, far better than as Marguerite which does not suit her. Sign. Mastropasque was admirable at Mimi. She has a real turn for acting, and her death at the end was unusually well carried out: her make-up was realistic in the extreme. Signor Arrighetti looked highly poetic, and sang well enough, but he vibrates his sustained notes to an annoying extent. The rest were fair after their kind, especially Signor Antonini, the 1st floor lodger. He looked so comfortable that one felt he should not have been disturbed, but he met the resellers with great equanimity. Signor Campanini had little enough in the way of hard work : the -more or less- felicitous continuity of the music called for few sudden effects or strenuous attention. But, where it was necessary, he was as always, accurate and impressive. Altogether, Signor Leoncavallo's opera is not without interest, and doubtless many who heard it will welcome it again, and compare it favorable with the rest of his work.

The weather since Saturday has been changeable. There were & continuous squalls from the West., accompanied by frequent and extraordinarily vivid flashes of lightning and thunder and heavy downpours of rain and hail. Strong gales prevailed yesterday. The black flag was ﬂying over Kom-el-Nadoura owing to the high sea running outside the harbour :
This morning opens cool and cloudy with a light North breeze and & rising Barometer. The weather promises to be settled to-day.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY, LTD.
div.p: REPORT OF DIRECTORS.
(Continuted from Saturday.)
Cairo Lands- the building plots which the company acquired at Ghezireh were realized in January, 1906, at a profit of about £20,000.

A site of 3,347 square metres, opposite the new Roman Catholic cathedral in Cairo, was purchased in May 1906, and has recently (Feb. 1907) been also sold at a substantially increased price, but the payments are spread over a period of two years.

The Company also acquired an estate on the Rodah Island of 33,658 square metres. It has not however been possible to deal with this propert yowing to a suit for pre-emption having been brought against the vendor.
FORT SAID TOWN SITES- The Company possesses two town sites in Port Said of an area of 6,140 square metres, which are increasing in value.

SOUDAN DEVELOPMENT AND EXPLORATION COMPANY- This Company, of which the new Egyptian company is practically the sole proprietor, reports very satisfactory progress in all departments of its business and especially in its Steamer service of the White and Blue Niles.
The Company's fleet has recently been enlarged and now comprises the following vessels:-
The Paddle-wheel Passenger Steamer "Cairo".
The Stern-wheel Passenger Steamer "Gordon Pasha".
The Steam Barge "Athara" (with passenger accomodation).
The Steam Barge "Kerreri".
The Steam Tug "Rahad".
The Steam Tug "Dunder".
The Steam Launch "Quien"
Fourteen Towing Barges (four under construction), Sailing Boats, Motor Launch, & s.

the earnings of the votes for the year ending 31st October, 1906 amounted to L.E. 17,469 as against L.E. 14,451 for the preceding twelve months. With these increased recipts, the profit shown by the Transport Department, after writing off depreciation, has been more than sufficient to provide the 3 per cent. interest guaranteed by the Sudan Government on the capital employed in this business, and one sequently no recourse has been necessary to the guarantee in question.

The Company has invested some £7,000 in the purchase of town sites in Khartoum on favourable terms. Some of these plots have already been sold at a good profit, and it is expected that the reminder will give equally satisfactory results. The Khartoum North Mills in which the company has a half-interest, have now been completed and are in full working order. Adjoining these mills the company possesses a half share of a property of 1,162 fed lanse on which experimental farming operations are being conducted. It successful, these operations will be carried out on a more extensive scale. With regard to the project for the agricultural development of a large tract of land near Khartoum North the preliminary survey mentioned in the last report has been made, and terms are now under discussion with the Sudan Government for the cessio of the lands to the company on the lease with option to purchase. A sketch plan is enclosed. The scheme is one requiring very careful study on both its engineering and financial aspects, as to which the company is being advised by its consulting engineer, Mr. BERESFORD, whose competence in these matters is universally recognized.

MENZALEH CANAL AND NAVIGATION COMPANY- This company, which was founded by the New Egyptian Company, has extended its operations during the past year. Its steamer service, which shows increasing returns has been open since the inst. February, 1906, between Matarieh and Ghetial Nassara (Damietta). The Menzaleh Company's channel will shortly be connected with the Suez Canal a Port Said, and the works are under survey for the completion with the Nile. Your Comapny still retains a considerable share interest in this promising enterprise.

INTERNATIONAL ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY TRUST COMPANY- The conclusion of the treaty between Great Britain, France, and Italy with regard to Abyssinia, which was signed in December last has now removed the political difficulties which have so long stood in hewey of the advancement of the Ethiopian Railway. Arrangements are now in course of completion for the construction by the present. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.
